WRITING.TEXT: I'm have almost the same stats as you (5'8'' and 120) and consider myself to be a solidly adult sized person but right now I'm wearing a pair of girls XL shorts from Target. The XL is actually a bit too big but I needed the extra length because work dress codes.
We would occasionally be allowed to have sugar cereal for a snack as a treat but the sweetest breakfast ever got was Kiks.

I took that one and while I like what it was aiming for I laughed out loud when I got the result that I am "not privileged at all"
Though I am a POC female with mental health issues (anorexia, depression, anxiety/panic attacks) and ADHD I still consider myself to be pretty darn privileged as I was raised by well educated parents in a safe, well off area with excellent public schools. Though I have mental health issues and an eating disorder, I had parents who could afford to get me treatment and had the time and motivation to educate themselves on what they could do to help me succeed. I have struggled, but I have always been in a situation that gave me access to the things I needed to overcome whatever I was faced with.
True, but that doesn't mean that they don't deserve the level of compensation that they get.

Doctors don't really make that much when you think about the amount of debt that they have to incur, the hours they work and the length of their training. To become a doctor (in the US) you need 4 years of undergrad, 4 years of medical school, at least 4 years of residency before you can fully start your career. While doctors make good money and are able to live comfortably not many are getting rich.
To me, adulthood feels like raising an unruly child, but I am both the parent and an unruly child.

I prefer phone calls to texting; I don't really like talking on the phone but it is just so much more efficient to call someone up when you need answers.
I'm not into the idea of casual sex. I would never judge someone for what they choose to do, but I personally see sex as something that should happen between 2 people in a loving, somewhat committed relationship. To me sex is something really intimate and emotional; if you only want physical pleasure just masturbate!
I'm religious. I know that a lot of people are, but as a college student who travels in pretty liberal circles I feel "old school" for going to church every Sunday and always praying before I go to sleep.
I'm probably going to get married young, but that isn't something I actively pursued; it is just the way things will probably work out. I don't really think there is any "ideal" age people should aim to get married at; heck, I don't even think people should feel like they have to get married at all!

If you live near a university or community college, I would contact their school of education to see if they have a list of students who are looking for childcare gigs. Even if they don't have a formal system a lot of schools will either let you put up flyers or pass your info on to professors who will share it with the students they think would be interested.
I'm a nursing student and a lot of my friends work for people who have contacted our department looking for help caring for their children with more complex medical needs.
I completely agree!

I have a pretty high tolerance for gross feet (I'm a ballet dancer and long distance runner) but I still consider the my foot when I got a cast off after 4 months to be one of the most disgusting things I have ever seen.
Sperm to a certain extent.
Like if I'm going to clog my arteries I should at least ENJOY doing it!

I struggle with anorexia with an orthorexic twist.
One time when I found out that my mom was making steak and potatoes for dinner I started crying and SCREAMED at her because in that moment I truly believed that she was trying to kill me with those toxic foods.
Orthorexia isn't choosing to turn down a piece of cake (or whatever) it is feeling like you can't EVER eat certain things or terrible things will happen.

I really like plain yogurt with a little bit of honey. I'm not trying to lose weight (I'm underweight) but I honestly prefer to add my own level of subtle sweetness than eat something thats overprocessed and usually nauseatingly sweet.
Life expectancy was also skewed by the huge numbers of young(ish) women who died in childbirth, and all of the men who died in industrial or farming accidents.

An LPN doesn't need a college degree to sit for the licensing exam; most are educated in 9-18 month long technical programs that focus on practical skills. LPNs and LVNs work under the supervision of an RN; legally they can't do anything without the direction of an RN or physician. They can do many of the same assessments as RNs but they are unable to interpret the data that they collect and make decisions about patient care. They tend to work in nursing homes, outpatient clinics and other subacute settings.
RNs must at least an associates degree from an accredited school to sit for the licensing exam, though most employers prefer candidates with a bachelors. RNs have more of a background in "hard science" and have to take courses such as anatomy, physiology, psychology, pharmacology, pathophysiology, human development, statistics, biochemistry, organic chemistry in addition to their nursing skills classes and clinicals. They are able to do more advanced procedures, create and implement patient care plans and delegate tasks. RNs also have the ability to specialize their practice and earn additional certifications that can allow them do perform more invasive or complicated procedures.

I mean there is; you shouldn't have a relative as your primary provider or surgeon but nobody is going to get in trouble for prescribing their kid an antibiotic for a straight forward strep infection once or twice.

Yeah that's what I've found.
My boyfriends mom is a doctor and while she doesn't treat her family she will prescribe for her husband or kids in a pinch if its a refill for an existing medication or a short term treatment for an acute problem (I got strep over a long weekend and she wrote for some ammox).

Yup. Doing abortions can be professionally and personally risky if you live in an area where a lot of people are against it, and there is no real financial incentive to perform them because clinics can't afford to pay docs that well (I mean they aren't destitute but they could make a lot more working in another setting).

I've been struggling with my eating disorder recently but I had been able to resist the urge to purge until Thursday and I'm so scared it will become a pattern again.
I can justify restricting and compulsively exercising as being "healthy" or into fitness, but no healthy person makes them self throw up.

I'm only a nursing student but I'm an outpatient pretty regularly because of my eating disorder and some medical complications.
I was admitted as an inpatient this winter because I had severe electrolyte imbalances and had lost a lot of weight after getting my wisdom teeth out so my outpatient team was worried about refeeding syndrome or a major cardiac event. I think the weirdest part was seeing people in my schools scrubs doing their clinicals on my unit (especially since I was in a children's hospital). Other than that it was just boring; I couldn't get out of bed for the first few days and it was the first week of the semester so I didn't even have much homework to do.
Just an FYI; a radiologist is just a medical doctor who specializes in radiology not a separate field!

YES!
I work at a camp and this summer I have a girl in my group who has "bathroom issues". I'm not sure what her exact diagnosis is (or if she has one) but she ended up having multiple accidents last summer because she was embarassed to ask to go to the bathroom and didn't want to feel like she was different. Plus, she is like 8 years old and decides that she can hold it if she doesn't want to leave an activity.
We have a lot of strategies to help her (code words etc.) but I think the best was making my whole group more comfortable with talking about their bodily functions; not in a gross way but just acknowledging that these things happen. I just frame it as another kind of diversity; some kids are super light and need to put on sunscreen more frequently, some kids are prone to overheating and need to take more breaks from running around, some people (me) have tiny bladders and need to go to the bathroom more.

In a perfect world I would get regular waxes and be hairless, but I am poor, lazy and I have to wear a swimsuit every day for work (I'm a camp counselor and I have to help supervise kids in the pool) so I just wear shorts.

Me: Mom was 35, dad was 33
Sister: Mom was 36, dad was 34
I really don't like Captain America as he is portrayed in the MCU. He just seems like a jerk.
Oh, they do it and premeds wear it.

I'm super glad that my program nipped this in the bud, we had a whole discussion about how the culture of playing the victim is really harmful to the nursing profession in our freshman intro course; if we want to be treated as the educated professionals we are we need to act like them.

Like are you buying 365 sets of sheet per year or are they just being washed and changed every day?
This sounds fantastic; I'm just curious about the logistics of your frivolity darn it!

I did the same thing, but it was any black man wearing a suit who was between the ages of 22 and 50.
My mom is white (I'm biracial) so I can't imagine how she felt having a little brown girl asking if every black man is her daddy...

The summer camp I work at drug tests as part of the hiring process and I also have to get drug tested before I do any clinical rotations in school (I'm a nursing major).
A failed drug test does not immediately get you kicked out of the program, but it will restrict what units you can rotate onto and you will be tested more frequently. I don't know of anyone who has failed; it's a super competitive program so nobody is taking any chances and we are warned WELL in advance about the test.
It honestly doesn't bother me at all; neither of these jobs can be safely done by someone who is impaired and in a healthcare setting you have to worry about people diverting drugs from patients.

Right now I'm a summer camp counselor and while it isn't my career it has showed me that I want to work with kids when I start my career (I'm a nursing major)
I love camp because I am able to connect with kids and help them grow without the pressure of being a teacher or a parent; I do my best to teach my kids new things and help them to become better people but at the end of the day as long as they have fun and stay safe I have done my job. I like solving little problems; getting a kid to stop crying or convincing someone to get in the pool after 3 weeks and seeing them have fun.

I'm a nursing student and I absolutely love this sentiment.
I truly believe that the best way to serve God is to serve others. I love science, blood and guts but at the end of the day I felt called to study nursing because I want to take care of people.

30A or 30B
I'm currently a 30E/28F and they just don't look right on my frame (I'm 5'8'', 120 pounds and muscular with no hips or ass so imagine a 14 year old boy with massive boobs); it seems like every time I go out some overly friendly drunk girl asks me if they are real!
Hey; you love your body so much that you are willing to do hard, uncomfortable things to make sure that it stays healthy! Screw what those crabs say, I'm proud of you!

My grandmother said no when her longterm boyfriend (they met after my grandfather passed away) proposed to her when they were on vacation IN PARIS. They are both in their 70's and she told him that marriage is entirely too much paperwork and upheaval with no benefit at their age.
When she explained her reasoning as to why she said no he basically dropped it and they are still happily together :)
They live on the same street, 2 houses apart and spend the winters living in sin in my Grandma's Florida house.

I work at a summer camp and the first thing I do when a kid says that they don't feel well is ask them if they are sad or if they miss their mom.
Like if you need to know organic chemistry or the origins and insertions of all of his muscles I've got you but otherwise I know nothing.

I'm not even short and I still get mistaken for a kid. Even other kids think that I'm one of them
I think the worst is when I get mistaken for a middle school boy. I know I have short hair and the hips of an adolescent male but I am a pretty darn feminine presenting person so I don't even know how this happens.

Me: 5'8'' and about 120 pounds

I love that he is so much taller than me and that he can make me feel like a dainty little princess. I loved him when he was a skinny nerd and I love him now that he is a college rower (those back muscles)
I'm not disabled myself, but I absolutely love seeing how people with disabilities modify their homes to better suit their needs.
Thats one of the upsides of being an adult who still sees doctors at a children's hospital: things are actually appropriately sized for me!

I mean as someone with an eating disorder; a lot of the things that we do can be healthy IF you are in a good mindset, have reasonable goals and don't take things to extremes. I justify my disordered behavior by telling myself that what I am doing is healthy, which would be true if I was practicing moderation and not already underweight.
For me its the difference between choosing not to eat a cookie because you want to stay under your goal and you indulged yesterday and feeling like you CAN'T eat a cookie because if you do something bad will happen. Same thing with exercise; it can be healthy to exercise everyday but it shouldn't be upsetting or cause anxiety if you have to take a day off.
Hey, screw her. I know I'm just a random internet stranger but I am SUPER proud of you!

A nutritionist doesn't even have to have a bachelors- anyone can call themselves a nutritionist because it is not a protected title.
Currently in the US you only need a to have bachelors degree and complete an approved dietetics internship to become an RD (though most end up getting a masters at some point because a lot of employers want them).
But they do need to do an internship after their undergrad before they can become a fully licensed RD, so there is some post-bac education.

Same here in the US; anyone can call themselves a 'nutritionist', but dietician and Registered Dietician are protected titles (like doctor or nurse) so you can only use them if you have proper credentials.

I am 5'8'' and about 120 pounds, so I am underweight for my height but I'm still a tall, adult sized person and it baffles me that I can comfortably fit into a lot of kids stuff.
I like older kids as individuals but I dislike them on a population level.

Unemotional nursing major checking in! I love gross things and like taking care of people; but I do not do feelings. Even at home I suck at using my words; I show people that I love them through my actions and I think that carries through to my professional life. I'm cool with it though; not everyone has to be touchy feely, nothing would get done if that was the case! I am a kind, caring person but I just don't understand emotions; I have learned how to deal with different situations by watching how others do it.

I'm kind of the opposite; I have always been at the low end of healthy or underweight for my height and I'm scared to know what I'll look like in the middle or the higher end where my doctor says I should be. I developed anorexia around the time I started puberty, so I never really reached my "adult" weight as I was either restricting or trying to maintain the lowest possible 'healthy' BMI.
I'll admit that I don't even feel 'good' at the low end of my range; I don't get a period and everything is boney so sitting down is basically never comfortable.
I'm 5'8'' and about 120 pounds; my highest weight was about 130 and my lowest was 113 but my doctor says that I should be 135-145 based on my growth charts and how my family is built.

It really bothers me that blind weights are becoming an FA 'thing'.
I have anorexia, and I get blind weights because I get way too fixated on numbers and right now I am not in a good enough place to deal with the urges I get when I see that I have gained or lost.
This doesn't mean that I am in denial about my weight; I know that I am underweight and I am told if I gain or lose a meaningful amount, but not having exact numbers makes it easier for me to cope.

I struggle with anorexia, and I am not at a point where I am able to know my exact weight because I get way too fixated on the specific numbers. I know that right now I'm underweight and I am told if my weight changes in a meaningful way.

WRITING.TITLE: Last minute tips for working with 5-6 year olds?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hey y'all! I'm not sure if this is the right place to post this, but I a camp counselor, and I'm looking for some advice before first day with my group of 5-6 year olds! I feel like I know a lot about kids in theory, but my experience comes from working in a preschool and doing camp with older kids, so this will be a new adventure and I would love to hear parents take on this age group.
The kids have a long day; before care starts at 7 am and after care ends at 6 pm, so while I only have them for the 7 hour camp day (9 am-4 pm) so some of them are spending almost 12 hours away from home! Most of our activities are pretty structured and the schedule is consistent from day to day (they always swim at the same time every etc.) so I'm not concerned about that aspect but I'm still a bit nervous.
I know that I'm not going to be perfect, and that nothing will really prepare me for my first day, but I'm a perfectionist and I really want to do everything I can to provide the best experience for the kids I am being trusted with.
Positive father-daughter relationships.
I like to go to the gym to study; I'll either read a textbook on the stairmaster or download the audio from one of my lectures and listen to it while I run!
Teeny tiny arms and legs!

BMI works for the vast majority of people, but it isn't perfect; which is why doctors use other metrics to get a full picture of a patients health. The biggest reason that they have to use other metrics is because the 'healthy' weight range is so big; peoples optimal weights are going to be at different points in that range.
There are also people who can be healthy at what is technically an unhealthy BMI; most doctors I have worked with aren't too concerned about a patient whose BMI is 26 if their other numbers are good and their weight stays stable.

I feel this. I have had vegans ARGUE with me that my doctors and dietician are wrong and it is completely reasonable for me to be vegan. I've had them tell me the reason I still struggle with my eating disorder is because I'm not vegan so obviously I Feel guilty when I eat.
Yeah, my anorexia and orthorexia will be completely cured if I just adopt this restrictive diet that is basically an ironclad excuse to never eat in public.
I wish I never learned how easy and (relatively) cheap paper plates/bowls are because now washing dishes just feels like so much effort.

Not OP, but I have been turned away from residential and outpatient facilities because I was medically unstable and they saw treating me as too much of a liability as I needed a hospital with 24/7 access to physicians.

I met many women in treatment who were like this; they went through periods of restriction, but they also binged so they were at a normal weight or overweight. I never once thought that their disorder was any less valid or serious than mine (anorexia), but their needs were different which is why we can't just let people use whatever label "feels" best to them.

I'm a nursing student with an eating disorder.
I know EXACTLY how I am damaging my body but I still tell myself that I'm fine.

I wish that I could be a full time, year round summer camp counselor.
I'm a nursing major so my realistic weird dream job is being on the medical staff at Disney World; you work in the first aid areas of the park and help coordinate stuff for guests with medical needs.

My issue with strangers asking about my racial/ethnic background ("what are you") isn't that they are asking an inherently rude question it is that they feel it is ok to ask for personal information from a person that they have never met before.
YES! I am BIRACIAL, not black.

My boyfriend grew up with a really awesome step-dad and I really admire people who take on that role.
His step-dad never tried to be his dad, he was always just another caring adult who would do whatever needed to be done and was as involved as the kids wanted him to be. He never forced himself into things but he always made sure that they knew he was available.

I'm not sure if I want to have kids or not, but it is basically my dream to be the cool aunt.
I love kids (I'm a full time camp counselor in the summer) and I have always been told that I am good with them, but I can barely remember to feed myself and I am way to anxious to be fully responsible for another human being any time soon.

Yup!
I grew up with an emotionally and verbally abusive father. I truly believe that he had good intentions, but he is very emotionally immature and probably has some unresolved issues from his own upbringing.
For me it was all about setting boundaries and accepting that what I am going to get is not what I really want. We will never be close, I will probably always stiffen when he tries to hug me and he is probably never going to understand the damage that he did to me, and I am ok with that, because I no longer need or want his approval.
I will never have a good relationship with my father, but things got SO much better when I accepted that our relationship will always be superficial, and found ways to have my emotional needs met in other ways.
I had a therapist who told me "you can't go to the hardware store and be angry that they don't sell cake mix. they have a lot of useful things, just not what you need at that moment" and I thought that was a really good way to look at difficult relationships.

Basically the only thing that makes me cry is seeing a positive father-daughter interaction.
Its ironic, because the reason I don't cry is because my father would scream at me and "give me a reason to cry" if I did.

I knew a girl who would write letters to the parents of the Columbine shooters talking about how much she loved their kids.
She was recently arrested for plotting to commit an act of domestic terrorism...
I only really notice a lower belly pooch if I'm constipated or really have to pee.
The uterus and ovaries are super small, and retroperitoneal (behind the intestines) so if anything is sticking out it is your lower GI tract and urinary bladder.

As someone who struggles with an eating disorder the best thing that you can do it be supportive! It must be so difficult to hear that she is hurting herself but it is really important that she continues to feel comfortable talking to you, I know one of the reasons I am so secretive is because I hate having to see how upset my mom gets.
You should really try to get her into some kind of treatment; I would talk to her guidance counselor. Even just therapy to deal with underlying issues, plus, a therapist can direct you to other resources and let you know if they think a higher level of care would be helpful. Early intervention is so important in treating eating disorders!
